text:
Well it did suggest going lower down the food chain, and fish are the most sustainable meat you can have. Most of veganism's benefits come from reducing land animal products. Fish could also be eaten in a way that actually benefits the ocean. For example, one solution that they didn't bring up was Marine Permaculture, which is essentially floating kelp forests that serve as building blocks for ocean ecosystems. This could help ocean species recover and would sequester billions of tons of C02, while providing enough kelp and fish to feed billions. Here's some sources if you're interested
https://www.climatefoundation.org/marine-permaculture.html
https://whatsyour2040.com/marine-permaculture/

text: I heard about a system being developed to help provide new homes for fish when coral reefs are being damaged by climate change. It's something called "reef balls." After someone dies and cremated, their ashes are combined with an eco friendly cement mixture, which is then made into little monuments. Those little monuments are customized, engraved, decorated, and then placed into the ocean as an artificial reef. The systems helps to preserve not only their memories, but also life on Earth. As King Mufasa would say, "And so we are all connected in the great Circle of Life." ‚ù§üåäüåû

text: You cant fight climate change by eating seaweed. Its not removing any carbon from the biosphere atmosphere exchange. Replacing worse methods is fine but if you want to sequester carbon effectively you need an ineffincy in the system to waste organic material to the deeper parts of the seafloor. Thats why the best aquaculture method for fighting climate change is for regional fisheries to be liscenced to fertilize tropical open sea, where the ocean would otherwise have extremely low biodensity and make use of an otherwise unused space in a similar way to how river mouths or sea mounts that cause upwelling affect the ocean.

author: Richard_N

text: That is a good point, but it all depends on accessibility and the conditions the fish require to survive. You need to be able to check the cages and nets and be able to harvest and will require things like boats and fuel which are expensive and can have their own impacts. Fish have basic environmental requirements for optimum survival for example water temperature, flow rate, dissolved oxygen quantities etc. which can't be controlled in the ocean so you have to find locations where that specific fish species will thrive. There usually are reasons why fish prefer certain locations to others and it wont help farming in a location where only some of your stock will thrive when you need to produce tons. There are also other issues like waves, which tend to be larger further out at sea (depending on where) that can destroy the cages or nets, and making it dangerous for your staff to access. Usually accessibility is the largest factor though since it will be one of the largest expenses for the business.

text: No, that's not what they're saying, but you have to admit the benefits of growing them in regenerative farms are intriguing. And, frankly, people will need to make changes in their lifestyle if we want to combat climate change and other environmental issues effectively. A lot of those changes will be related to our food, by wasting less of it, and reducing our consumption of animals and animal products or switching to more sustainable products, like shellfish.
author: Curran Frank

text: Lots of people are going to be very stubborn about changing the way they live to a more sustainable lifestyle. They've grown used to their normal behavior and many won't want to modify it just because they don't want to. Hopefully the younger generations will be able to adapt more easily in the future.

text: Globin347 You're right, it's the cow farts. The glowing ball of plasma in the sky has no effect on the temperature of the earth.
author: Bearly Listening

text:
¬†@Bearly Listening¬† I never said the sun had no effect on earth's temperature. I merely said it was not the driving force of climate change. You are twisting my words in a way that invalidates anything I say.


I should also mention... If you actually understood the science, you'd know that the sun's output is actually decreasing at the moment. It's not a drastic change, but it does make it clear that the sun is not the cause.


And while the cow farts are a significant part of the problem and need to be addresssed, the biggest sources of excess gas are cars and power plants.
author: Globin347

text: Globin347 So please tell me, oh wise one, exactly what percentage of the temperature is due to the sun's intensity, and what percentage is due to cow farts?
author: Bearly Listening

text: Globin347 'Climate change' isn't even a scientifically measurable term. If you're talking about temperature, then you have to establish a starting point. But the earth has been much hotter and colder in the past, so how can you possibly claim to know what the exact temperature should be? The climate has always been changing and always will.
author: Bearly Listening

text:
¬†@Bearly Listening¬† 

To begin, The sun's output has not significantly increased since we've been measuring it. In addition, while the lower atmosphere is warming at a dangerous rate, the upper atmosphere is actually cooling down. This makes it fairly clear that the sun is not responsible for the current spot of global warming- thus, the percentage of change due to changes in solar output is 0%.
https://www.carbonbrief.org/why-the-sun-is-not-responsible-for-recent-climate-change

The next logical thing to consider is natural emissions of greenhouse gasses. Indeed, volcanoes, animal death, and emissions due to wildlife ("deer farts", if you will), release millions of tons of greenhouse gasses into the atmosphere every year.

However, there also exist natural processes that remove these greenhouse gasses (primarily carbon and methane) from the air. These include photosynthesis and rain (for an example of the latter, look at how much cleaner Shanghai's air is after a rainstorm).

Carbon and methane can be stored in the air, in rocks (such as limestone), in the sea, or in living things.

https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/ecology/biogeochemical-cycles/a/the-carbon-cycle

https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/features/CarbonCycle

Overall, the natural carbon cycle is fairly balanced. It does shift, but that takes a few million years at least. As carbon is released into the atmosphere by volcanoes and respiration, it is absorbed back by photosynthesis, and by the ocean, which gradually turns it into calcium carbonate, which sinks to the bottom and becomes limestone.

This process results in regular, predictable patterns of warming and cooling called milankovitch cycles. As solar and orbital patterns vary, earth's temperature increases, which results in more greenhouse gasses (yes, greenhouse gasses are (normally) initially released due to outside interference), which in turn drives further warming. This pattern reverses when factors such as earth's precession and the eccentricity of it's orbit shift, resulting in longer winters. This causes formation of sea ice, which in turn makes the earth more reflective, further dropping temperatures.

In case you're wondering, we know all this due to ice cores, which trap pockets of air in ice, thus allowing us to get little glimpses of the chemical makeup of the atmosphere in the past, as well as due to the fossil record, due to the chemical makeup of rock layers, tree rings, and due to astrological predictions. The science as a whole is called paleoclimatology, and there are more than a few experts in the field to work to get us this information.


https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/news/what-paleoclimatology


https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/data-access/paleoclimatology-data


https://www.britannica.com/science/paleoclimatology


https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/features/Paleoclimatology_Understanding


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=to7lxbCDBiE



¬†However, human actions upset this balance by pumping out enormous amounts of greenhouse gasses into the atmosphere- and the specfic sources of our greenhouse gasses are coal and oil, which would normally be leaked into the atmosphere very slowly. Because we add roughly a 92 Gigatons of carbon to the atmosphere every year (not to mention methane, which is more powerful than carbon as a greenhoouse gas), but do nothing to take additional carbon and methane from the atmosphere, the result is a net increase in the amount of greenhouse gasses, which can shift the climate dramatically. 

 https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-1-d&q=how+much+carbon+do+we+add+to+the+atmosphere

For specific details on what we're doing, the biggest human sources of carbon are transportation, electricity, power, the creation of concrete (which must release carbon dioxide as part of the chemical reactions involved), waste and household products, and agriculture.

Agriculture emits about 9% of human caused greenhouse gasses, so to answer your question, the cow farts are a relatively small part of the equation. However, that doesn't mean that reducing it won't improve the situation. By reducing said cow farts, as well as investing into renewable energy, changing lifestyles to be less wasteful, and putting stricter regulations on corporate practices, we can dramatically lower our carbon output, and thus lessen the impact on our climate for future generations.

Apologies for the time it took to put all this together, and for showing you a first draft. I would have put a bit more time into it, but I have places to be later today.
author: Globin347

text:
¬†@Bearly Listening¬† Apologies it took me so long to get that last comment in. Anyway, you're half right. The climate has always been changing- but it changes in a very predictable manner. 



I put a bunch of sources in the short essay I'm calling a comment (in this chain), so I'll just direct you there rather than repost the same sources here.
author: Globin347

text: Globin347 Lol, took you long to copy and paste spam propaganda.  You didn't answer my question. What starting point are you using to assess the change in temperature? And what makes you think there should be any ice on the earth? After all, ice always starts as water first.
author: Bearly Listening

text: Globin347 Thanks for mentioning ice cores. That's how we know that the temperature has been much higher and much lower in the past, due to Milankovitch cycles as well as meteor impacts and other catastrophes. The ice cores are also how we know that   temperature drives CO2, not the other way around. CO2 is a lagging indicator and is associated with higher oxygen levels as well. As the oceans warm, more CO2 moves from the water to the atmosphere. Do you even have any clue what percentage of the atmosphere is composed of CO2? It's a trace gas. An argument could easily be made that we are dramatically CO2 deficient, given that all plants depend on CO2 to produce oxygen which we desperately need. If you had any interest in current scientific research, you would know that the most recent evidence shows that atmospheric composition has absolutely no effect on temperature. Rather temperature can be predicted precisely across the solar system based on distance from the Sun and atmospheric density alone.
author: Bearly Listening

text:
¬†@Bearly Listening¬† Well, there is the fact that the climate over the past few decades has been climbing faster than the overall rate of change over the past several hundred thousand years... 

https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-atmospheric-carbon-dioxide

And the fact that extinction across the board is rising to nearly unprecidented levels.

https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-48584515

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/feb/10/plummeting-insect-numbers-threaten-collapse-of-nature

https://www.iflscience.com/plants-and-animals/current-extinction-rate-10-times-worse-previously-thought/

These suggest that something is wrong, at the very least. Of course, there are a number of things that could be wrong other than the climate... 

In any case, I'm nearly out of time for today, so I guess I'll have to concede this argument to you for the time being.
author: Globin347
